Among the many resource utilization routes of CO2, the reaction of CO2 with epoxides to synthesis cyclic carbonates is a well-established method, which is not only environmentally friendly but also in line with atomic economy for heterogeneous catalysts. Aimed at insufficient exposure of active sites and poor catalytic activity, a series of P[VImX][Br] Poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs) catalysts was developed with different porous structure. PILs catalysts with hierarchical porous structure and particle size were obtained by adjusting the ratio of ILs and DVB monomer. When the ratio of ILs increased, the specific surface area and the degree of dispersion of the particles firstly increased and then decreased, and the larger specific surface area and the degree of dispersion were more favorable for the full exposure of the active sites, which in turn improved the catalytic activity. Among them, the optimal ratio of ILs is 0.4 (P[VIm0.4][Br]), which has relatively large specific surface area and high degree of dispersion, and the highest catalytic activity, and the conversion rate of propylene oxide (PO) reaches 95 %. In addition, the catalyst exhibited good recoverability after five cycles and obtained a wide substrate applicability. This paper provides a new idea for tuning the structure of PILs for high efficient catalysis. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Poly(ionic liquid)s Carbon dioxide Cycloaddition Cyclic carbonate Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction CO2 is the main component of greenhouse gasses. Carbon Capture, Utilization and Storage (CCUS) is currently recognized as the most effective carbon emission reduction and carbon-negative technology in the world. Among the many carbon fixation routes, the synthesis of cyclic carbonate from CO2 and epoxides is a well established route [1–3]. The product, cyclic carbonate, is an important bulk chemical that can be used as battery electrolyte, polar solvent, and chemical intermediate[4,5]. Therefore, a catalyst with low energy consumption and high catalytic efficiency at low cost has become the main research object to promote the large-scale application of this technology. Since the 1960s, scientific workers all over the world have done a lot of research on catalysts for this reaction and developed a variety of catalysts for this reaction, among which the main homogeneous catalysts are alkali metals, metal complexes, heteropoly acids, ionic liquids (ILs), etc.[6–10]. The heterogeneous catalysts include metal oxides, modified molecular sieves and loaded catalysts, polymers, etc[1,11-13]. Although homogeneous catalysts exhibit high catalytic activity in the reaction process, their complex separation process, high recovery energy consumption and cost, thus limit their application in industrial production. Although, the emergence of heterogeneous catalysts is a good solution to the above problems, effectively simplifying the separation process and promising to reduce energy consumption and compress costs. However, in heterogeneous catalysts for catalyzing cycloaddition reactions, the problems of low catalytic activity and poor stability still exist [14]. ILs have a series of unique and excellent properties, such as low melting point and saturation vapor pressure, good solubility, high catalytic activity and extreme designability, which provide a very broad scope for the application of ILs [15–18]. Deng[19] et al. first reported the use of imidazolium-based ILs to catalyze CO2 cycloaddition reactions, and the conversion could reach 100 % at 110 ℃, 6 h, CO2 pressure of 2.5 MPa, but since ILs as a homogeneous catalyst still have a series of unsolvable problems, such as difficult separation, easy loss, etc., the heterogeneous of ILs is an excellent way to solve the above problems. Poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs) can retain the advantages of safe and efficient environmental protection of ILs catalysis, but also has the advantages of easy separation of heterogeneous catalysts, which can realize repeated catalytic conversion, etc., providing new possibilities for ILs catalysts in industrial applications [20–23]. Han[24] et al. prepared PILs for catalytic cycloaddition reactions by one-step polymerization and concluded that fixation of ILs on the polymer backbone is an effective way to improve the catalytic activity and 97.4 % yield was obtained at a catalyst amount of 0.6 mol%, 6 MPa CO2, 383 K, 7 h. The good activity and stability were maintained while being easy to separate. However, the PILs existing catalysts suffer from the problem that the active sites are difficult to be fully dispersed and exposed, resulting in low catalytic activity [25]. Porous polymers have the advantage of rich pore structure with adjustable specific surface area, which can fully expose the active sites and thus improve the catalytic activity [26]. Wang[27] and et al. prepared a PILs catalyst with mesoporous structure and high specific surface area. The catalyst showed high conversion and selectivity in the reaction. Therefore the development of catalysts for PILs with controllable multi-porous structure is essential. In the construction of porous structures, hierarchical porous structure modulation is essential for the performance of PILs. Yu m[28] et al. prepared a series of materials with multilevel pore structure, and the study showed that the multilevel pore structure could effectively improve the adsorption performance of the materials. Chen [29] et al. realized the modulation of the spatial structure such as multi-stage shape and the pore structure by changing the ratio of monomer to cross-linking agent, and then modulated the gas adsorption performance of PILs, which showed the largest specific surface area and the strongest adsorption capacity for CO2 when the ratio of ILs to cross-linking agent was 1:2. Taking this as inspiration, it is hoped that the hierarchical porous structure of PILs can be modulated by regulating the ratio of ILs. Therefore, in this paper, we hope to obtain hierarchical pore-structured PILs catalysts with controllable spatial structure by modulating the ILs ratio. In order to obtain hierarchical pore structures, the idea of multistage polymerization of polymers can be borrowed[30]. Using the process of solution polymerization, the oligomer will precipitate in the form of droplets and then grow up, the amphiphilicity of the initial precipitated droplets can be regulated by controlling the proportion of ILs to obtain smaller and stable droplets. Microporous structures are created from molecules with rigid structures in the droplets, mesopores are created by the stacking of smaller droplets, and macropores are created by the stacking of large clusters [31]. In this paper, PILs catalysts with hierarchical porous structure were obtained by modulating the ILs ratio of PILs and used to catalyzed cycloaddition reactions. Combined with the analytical characterization and activity evaluation, the influence law between different ILs ratios on the structure and properties of the PILs was investigated, and the best catalysts were preferentially selected. Then, the recyclability and substrate suitability of the selected catalysts were measured. This paper provides a new research idea to regulate the spatial structure of PILs, aiming to improved PILs catalytic activity. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of 1-ethyl-3-ethylimidazolium bromide VEIMBr Vinyl imidazole (18.8 g, 0.2 mol) was dissolved in deionized water in a round bottom flash equipped with condenser. After that, ethyl bromide (19.6 g, 0.18 mol) was blent in the solution gently with dropping funnel. The mixed solution was stirred at 50 °C for 24 h. Afterward, the solvent was removed by evaporation, the obtained solid was then washed with ethyl acetate for three times and dried under vacuum at 50 °C for 24 h to get the product at last. 2.2 Preparation of Poly(ionic liquid)s P[VImX][Br] Seven kinds of ILs with different ratios (P[VImX][Br], X(molar ratio of IL monomer to DVB)= (1, 0.8, 0.6, 0.5, 0.4, 0.2, 0) were synthesized. The classical procedure of synthesizing PIL P[VIm0.5][Br] was as follows: DVB (6.5 g, 0.05 mol) and 1-ethyl-3-ethylimidazolium bromide was dissolved in acetonitrile in a three-necked flask (100 ml) equipped with condenser and Schlenk technique. The mixed solution was stirred for 10 min. Then, AIBN (0.06 % of reactants) was added in the solution and the reaction was kept under inert gas protection by providing N2 atmosphere with Schlenk technique. Afterward, the solvent was removed by filter after reaction, the obtained solid was then washed with ethyl acetate for three times and dried under vacuum at 50 °C for 24 h to get the P[VIm0.5][Br] at last. Other PILs were also prepared according to the similar procedure. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation procedure Taking P[VIM0.5][Br] as an example, procedure for the synthesis of propylene carbonate. The cycloaddition reaction was conducted in a 25 mL micro-reactor with pressure and temperature sensors. Firstly, 1.72 g of PO and 0.2 g PILs were added into it (The active component is 2 % of the reactant). After sealing the reactor, replace the air inside the reactor with CO2 and then the reactor was started to heat. After that, increase the pressure to 2.5 MPa once the reactor's temperature reached 120 °C and keep the valve open to ensure reactor's pressure at 2.5 MPa during the reaction, the reaction time was 2 h. After that, the reactor was cooled down to room temperature. Afterwards, the product was collected by pipette and analyzed by gas chromatography (GC). 2.4 The characteristic analysis of PILs Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out to detect thermal stability which was proceeded with DTG-60H thermal analyzer (Shimadzu, Japan) in a N2 circumstance, whose temperature programming was set at a rate of 10 °Cmin−1. SEM instrument (JSM6700 F, JEOL) and a TEM instrument (JEM2100F, JEOL) were applied to get surface morphologies of PILs. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of PILs that were used to confirm the corresponding groups were recorded on Thermo Nicolet 380 with KBr as a reference. Elemental compositions (C/H/N) were analyzed on a Vario EL Cube elemental analyzer to estimate the content of ILs in PILs. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore distribution curves were obtained by Micromeritics porosimeter (ASAP-2020 HD88), the desorption stage was set at 80 °C for 4 h. The structure and pore structure of the samples were analyzed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) with JEM 2100F. The samples were dispersed with methanol and then added to the copper net by drops and placed in the fume hood for natural drying. The conversion and selectivity were examined via a GC system (Agilent 7890) with a FID detector and HP-5 capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization To determine the structure of PILs, Fourier transform infrared spectra were performed for P[VIm0.2][Br], P[VIm0.4][Br], P[VIm0.5][Br], P[VIm0.6][Br], and P[VIm0.8][Br], respectively, as shown in Fig. 1 . The peak near 3050 cm−1 is caused by the CH stretching vibration on the imidazole cation, the peak near 1560 cm−1 is originated from the imidazole ring backbone vibration, and 1172 cm−1 is caused by the stretching vibration of the imidazole ring, which proves the presence of imidazole IL in the sample. The appearance of the characteristic peak near 830 cm−1 is the para-substitution of the benzene ring, which proves the presence of divinylbenzene (DVB) in the sample. Elemental analysis was performed to determine the amount of supported ILs. As can be seen from the analytical results (Table 1 ), the actual values do not differ much from the theoretical values, which also confirms the successful polymerization in proportion to the targeted PILs. Thermogravimetric characterization was also performed on a series of samples to investigate the thermal stability of the samples, and the results are shown in Fig. 2 . The initial weight loss around 250 °C is attributed to the degradation of the ILs. The weight loss at around 430 °C was attributed to the degradation of the cross-linker DVB, proving that all PILs have good thermal stability. We can see that the sample P[VIm0.4][Br] has the hightest thermal stability and could endure temperature about 280 °C. In addition, the analysis of the platform position in the middle of the two weight loss points gives similar results to the elemental analysis and confirms the successful polymerization of the PILs in proportion. In order to analyze the pore structure and specific surface area of PILs, nitrogen adsorption and desorption experiments were performed, as shown in Fig. 3 . From P[VIM0.4][Br] with the IL ratio of 0.4 with the increase of the ratio, the curve of the low-pressure region gradually shifted to the X-axis, indicating that P[VIM0.4][Br] has the strongest binding ability with the gas, and then gradually weakened, with a significant decrease between the IL ratio of 0.5–0.6. The hysteresis loop also transitions from H4 to H3 type, and it can be learned that the micropores formed by narrow cleavage pores decrease to disappear only the mesopores and macropores formed by the accumulation of lamellar particles remain. The surface area data of the samples can also verify the above analysis, as shown in Table 2 , the micropores appear from IL ratio of 0.4 to 0.5 and then disappear. This may be a microporous structure formed by the intermolecular stacking of ILs with DVB. And the ratio is at 0.4–0.5, a multistage pore structure occurs, and the specific surface area is almost uniformly distributed within the microporous,mesoporous,macroporous. From the pore volume distribution plots (Fig. 3b), it can be seen that P[VIm0.4][Br] and P[VIm0.5][Br] showed a higher peak around 3 nm in the mesopore interval and a smaller peak around 5 nm, which may be the reason why these two samples were still higher than the other samples after deduction of the micropore area, while P[VIm0.4][Br] and P [VIm0.6][Br] have a larger peak around 60 nm in the macroporous region, which leads to the fact that P[VIm0.6][Br] is significantly higher than the other two samples even though it is not mesoporous, which is consistent with the results of the isothermal curves in which P[VIm0.6][Br] has a large H3-type hysteresis loop. In summary P[VIm0.4][Br] with an ILs percentage of 0.4 has a multistage pore structure, in which the pore size is distributed in the microporous, mesoporous, and macroporous intervals. The presence of micropores facilitates a fuller exposure of the active sites, while the presence of mesopores and macropores facilitates the rapid entry and exit of the reacting molecules. In short, the high specific surface area and the ability to bind with gasses facilitates the contact between the catalyst and the reactants, which is favorable for the reaction. To characterize the apparent morphology and structural features of the PILs, the samples were characterized by EDS, SEM and TEM, as shown in Fig. 4 , taking P[VIm0.4][Br] as an example, it can be seen from the EDS results (Fig. 4a) that the active component Br- of the catalyst is uniformly distributed on the surface of the samples. The SEM images of the samples show that the pores of the samples are formed by the accumulation of lamellar particles, and the comparison between P[VIm0.4][Br] (Fig. 4a) and the other two samples (Fig. 4c and e) shows that the lamellar particles of P[VIm0.4][Br] are smaller and have more tightly packed pores. In contrast, the lamellar particles of P[VIm0.6][Br] (Fig. 4c) are significantly larger and thus form larger and fewer stacking pores, which corroborates with the pore volume data. The TEM photographs of the samples (Fig. 4b) also confirm the lamellar structure and the presence of stacking pores, which is consistent with the BET results. Fig. 4f shows that the polymer with only cross-linker DVB does not form a lamellar structure, but rather spherical particles with a diameter of about 1 µm. The addition of IL changes the structure of the polymer to a large extent, thus also proving that the polymer with only cross-linker or ILs cannot form a lamellar structure and thus stacking pores. While a moderate ratio ensures that the particles are copolymerized from the inside out, when the ratio of ILs is too large, it will lead to the self-polymerization of ILs at the late stage of polymerization, which will lead to the excessive entanglement of flexible chain segments on the surface of the particles and block the pore structure (Fig. 4e). When the proportion of DVB is too large, it will lead to too many residual double bonds on the surface of the particles, and when the particles collide with each other to form larger and denser particles, resulting in an increase in the base particle size and a decrease in the stacking holes (Fig. 4c). In order to characterize the dispersion of the synthesized catalyst P[VImX][Br] in the reaction system, it was subjected to laser particle size characterization, and the results are shown in Fig. 5 . From the figure, it can be seen that with the increase of the proportion of ILs in the catalyst, the particle size distribution has a tendency to become concentrated and smaller first and then dispersed and larger. Among them, the PILs P[VIm0.4][Br] with a proportion of 0.4 has the most concentrated particle size distribution and the particle size distribution is mainly concentrated around 15 nm, which is the smallest among all the samples. When the proportion of ILs is greater than 0.4, the particle size distribution shows two peaks, one within 100 nm and the other around 270 nm. This may be due to an excess of ILs so that the long flexible chain segments formed in the later stages of polymerization become entangled with each other leading to the formation of clusters in the base particles. And when the proportion of ILs is less than 0.4, the particle size distribution is wider, and the highest peak is around 300 nm, which indicates that the base particle size of P[VIm0.2][Br] is larger, which may be due to the excessive cross-linking agent resulting too many double bonds remaining on the surface of base particles becoming larger due to the tight bonding during the later stages of polymerization. From the variation of particle size in the range of 0–9 nm, it can be seen that there exists a peak around 1.5 nm at the ratio of ILs of 0.4–0.5, which is absent in other samples. Combined with the phenomenon that a large portion of mesopores with diameters around 3 nm exists only when the ratio of ILs is 0.4–0.5 (which leads to a significant increase in the ratio of mesopores) in the plots of the pore size distribution in nitrogen desorption, the reason for the formation of smaller mesopores can be hypothesized. Small particles of about 1.5 nm are formed in the pre-polymerization stage, and mesopores of about 3 nm are formed from the stacking of these small particles, and medium-sized particles of about 15 nm are formed, and then larger pores and larger particles are formed from the stacking of the medium-sized particles. Additionally ILs and DVB are hydrophilic and lipophilic respectively, too much hydrophilicity results in the formation of smaller and unstable micelles, as evidenced by the small peak at 0.3 nm for 0.6–0.8, however the micelles that it can form are unstable and can quickly entangle to form large particles. Whereas excess DVB has a higher lipophilicity, this causes the oligomer to form very large particles in the solvent that precipitate directly (around 300 nm) [32]. This also explains the ratio of 0.8 and 0.2 with only trace amounts of stacked macropores. A more concentrated and smaller particle size is more favorable for dispersion in the reaction system, which facilitates the contact between the reaction substrate and the active site, and thus improves the catalytic activity [33]. 3.2 Catalytic cycloaddition of CO2 into cyclic carbonates The catalytic activity of a series of PILs P[VImX][Br] for the synthesis of propylene carbonate investigated using PO as an example. The results are shown in the Table 3 , the conversion of propylene oxide to propylene carbonate was only 5 % in the polymer completely without IL. After that, the catalytic activity increased significantly with the increase of IL addition, and the conversion increased from 5 % without IL to 95 % at 40 % addition of ILs. And then, as the addition amount continued to increase, the catalytic activity decreased gradually from 95 % at the beginning of P[VIm0.4][Br] to 55 % at P[VIm1.0][Br] without cross-linking agent. It is speculated that the possible reason is that the experimentally synthesized P[VIm1.0][Br] samples are transparent gels with no visible pore structure on the surface at all, and only a portion of the active sites on the surface can play a catalytic role in the whole PILs. The pattern of change in catalytic activity is highly consistent with the test results nitrogen desorption test and particle size distribution. This indicates that the large specific surface area, multilevel pore structure and centralized particle size distribution can effectively increase the exposure of the active sites in the catalyst, which is conducive to the full utilization of the active sites of ILs in the catalyst, thus improving the catalytic activity. And the most catalytically active P[VIm0.4][Br] is comparable to the activity of the monomer (VEIMBr). 3.3 Evaluation of substrate suitability of P[VIm0.4][Br] To further investigate the general applicability of P[VIm0.4][Br], the catalytic activity of epoxides with different substrates was evaluated under experimental conditions of 120 °C, 2 h, 2.5 MPa, 2 mol%. The results are shown in Table 4 . P[VIm0.4][Br] can effectively catalyze the generation of the corresponding cyclic carbonates from various epoxides with high conversion and selectivity. The conversions of epoxycyclohexane and epichlorohydrin were relatively low due to the influence of the steric hindrance of epoxides. 3.4 Evaluation of recyclability of P[VIm0.4][Br] The reusability of the sample was explored under the same reaction conditions (2 mol% of PO,120 °C, 2 h, 2.5 MPa), and the catalyst was recovered by centrifugal filtration after each run washed three times with ethanol, acetonitrile, and dried under vacuum afterwards. It was used for the next cycle and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . P[VIm0.4][Br] showed good reusability after five runs, and the selectivity of PC remained at 99 % with a slight decrease in conversion. This may be due to the loss of trace amounts during the recycling process. However, the catalyst still maintained high activity overall, thus proving that P[VIm0.4][Br] is a reusable catalyst. Afterwards, the structures of the catalysts after five cycles were compared with those of the fresh catalysts, and the FT-IR characterization results are shown in Fig. 7 , which show that the catalysts after cycling still retained the active sites of the imidazole moiety. It is proved that P[VIm0.4][Br] is a reusable catalyst. 3.5 In-depth study of active site distribution In order to characterize the active site distribution of the synthesized PILs, XPS characterization of P[VIm0.4][Br] was carried out, and in order to facilitate the comparison, two samples with the largest differences in multilevel structure and particle size distributions, P[VIm0.4][Br] and P[VIm0.2][Br], were selected for the experiment, and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . two peaks appeared for Br 3d located at 66.96–68.83 eV and 65.85–66.34 eV respectively which are the peaks of Br− in the PILs, and it can be seen that 66.96 eV and 65.8 eV of P[VIm0.4][Br] are significantly lower than those of P[VIm0.2][Br], which are 68.83 eV and 66.34 eV. This suggests that P[VIm0.4][Br] with a hierarchical pore structure and higher dispersion has a lower anionic and cationic binding energy. The lower anionic binding energy contributes to the freeing of Br− during the catalytic process, which improves the catalytic activity. The two peaks appearing in the N 1 s spectra were 399.73–399.85 eV and 397.75–397.95 eV are the two characteristic peaks of N on imidazole. Comparison shows that 399.73 eV and 397.75 eV for P[VIm0.4][Br] are lower than 399.85 eV and 397.95 eV for P[VIm0.2][Br]. This indicates that the CN binding energy of P[VIm0.4][Br] on the imidazole ring is lower, which favors CH extension, thus making it easier for the H on the imidazole ring to interact with the PO and promote PO ring opening. Subsequently, in support of the above speculation about the interaction of the imidazole ring with PO in the active site, the mixture of ILs monomers VEIMBr, VEIMBr and PO and PO respectively, was subjected to NMR characterization, the result is shown in the Fig. 9 . In Fig. 9a, the three peaks between 7.9–10.0 ppm represent the three H's on the imidazole ring, and it can be seen that the H's on the imidazole ring in VEIMBr were all shifted after co-mingling with PO, which indicates that the electron cloud on the imidazole ring was changed, and thus it can be hypothesized that the H's on the imidazole interacted with PO. In Figure 9b, the four peaks marked by dashed lines represent the H on PO, and it can be seen that the electron cloud of PO also changed after mixing with ILs. In summary, it can be hypothesized that PO will interact with the H on imidazole, prompting PO to undergo ring opening. This could support the speculation in the XPS N1 results for lower binding energies favoring PO loop opening. Based on these conclusions, a possible catalytic mechanism was proposed, in which first the epoxides interacts with H on the imidazole ring to form a hydrogen bond, and Br− interacts with C on the epoxides, which together lead to epoxides ring-opening, followed by the insertion of CO2 to form a cyclic carbonate, as shown in Fig. 10 . 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of heterogeneous PILs catalysts with different contents of imidazolium-based ILs were successfully synthesized and characterized in this study for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2, and the modulation of the PILs spatial structure was achieved by different ILs additions. With the increase of ILs content in the PILs, the surface area of the catalysts showed a trend of increasing and then decreasing. And at 40 % −50 % of the ILs ratio appeared a high degree of microporosity occurs and a certain amount of meso‑ and macroporous organization is maintained. This is accompanied by smaller particles and greater dispersion. These structural changes lead to changes in the catalytic activity of the PILs. Among all the prepared PILs, P[VIm0.4][Br] catalyst showed optimal activity at 40 % ILs ratio, with conversion of PO 95 %. The excellent catalytic activity is mainly attributed to the high surface area, the hierarchical pore structure and the high dispersion of the active sites. In addition, the catalyst has good reusability and can be reused for five times with very little change in activity, the catalyst also has good substrate suitability. And proposed a possible catalytic mechanism. This study provides a new idea to regulate the structures of PILs catalysts for structural control and provides a new way to convert CO2 to high value-added chemicals. coredata.dc:description: Among the many resource utilization routes of CO2, the reaction of CO2 with epoxides to synthesis cyclic carbonates is a well-established method, which is not only environmentally friendly but also in line with atomic economy for heterogeneous catalysts. Aimed at insufficient exposure of active sites and poor catalytic activity, a series of P[VImX][Br] Poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs) catalysts was developed with different porous structure. PILs catalysts with hierarchical porous structure and particle size were obtained by adjusting the ratio of ILs and DVB monomer. When the ratio of ILs increased, the specific surface area and the degree of dispersion of the particles firstly increased and then decreased, and the larger specific surface area and the degree of dispersion were more favorable for the full exposure of the active sites, which in turn improved the catalytic activity. Among them, the optimal ratio of ILs is 0.4 (P[VIm0.4][Br]), which has relatively large specific surface area and high degree of dispersion, and the highest catalytic activity, and the conversion rate of propylene oxide (PO) reaches 95 %. In addition, the catalyst exhibited good recoverability after five cycles and obtained a wide substrate applicability. This paper provides a new idea for tuning the structure of PILs for high efficient catalysis.
coredata.dc:title: Spatial structure modulation of Poly(ionic liquid)s with hierarchical porous structure for efficiently catalytic conversion of CO2 into cyclic carbonates
